body:
This should resolve the bug mentioned in [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31311#issuecomment-2511024970).

The reproduction method is to open a relatively large file (so the server needs some time to process the request), and then immediately execute `:bd`. Once the request is completed, the handler will obtain the bufstate of a buffer already unloaded.

Should this fix be applied at a lower level, that is, should all pending requests of the client attached to the buffer be immediately canceled after the buffer is unloaded?

comment_data.body:
I could see a caller accidentally sending buf=0 expecting it to mean current buffer. So we should probably handle that (or throw an error).

```suggestion
  local bufnr = filter.bufnr and vim._resolve_bufnr(filter.bufnr) or nil
```

comment_regular_data.body:
> Should this fix be applied at a lower level, that is, should all pending requests of the client attached to the buffer be immediately canceled after the buffer is unloaded?

Yeah, I personally think that this cancellation should happen for all pending requests and not only for folding ranges.

I just thought of an edge case where jumping through `buf.reference` and similar methods may still require the request to not be canceled. At this point, the buffer in the request is the source rather than the target.

> I just thought of an edge case where jumping through `buf.reference` and similar methods may still require the request to not be canceled. At this point, the buffer in the request is the source rather than the target.

Maybe we could enumerate the explicit methods that we don't want to cancel, in that low-level handler.

> Maybe we could enumerate the explicit methods that we don't want to cancel, in that low-level handler.

I am concerned about the methods in protocol extensions, as their behavior is completely uncertain. However, I might be overthinking it a bit; the cancellation of requests performed on a buffer after it has been deleted should be an expected behavior. I will handle it at a lower level later if this is the consensus.

However, I might be overthinking it a bit; the cancellation of requests performed on a buffer after it has been deleted should be an expected behavior. I will handle it at a lower level later if this is the consensus.

If by protocol extensions you mean custom messages that aren't specified in the LSP, then those would need special server/client handlers outside of Neovim, so I wouldn't worry about that.

The "handling at a lower level" I am thinking of refers to canceling all pending requests sent via `client:request` when the client detaches from a buffer. I think this should affect all applications?
Sorry I complicated this issue. Based on @justinmk's suggestion, I extracted a new `util._cancel_requests` to help us fix this potential bug that cannot be stably reproduced first.
Is it correct there is no `method = method` in the argument table of `M._cancel_requests()` at L2200?
@hexium310 Oops, that's not intended. Thank you for mentioning that. I'm currently checking https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/32277, I will create a PR for both of them later.
